If the sauce in the pot is too thin, place it on the stovetop over medium heat and simmer for 5-10 minutes until it thickens to your desired consistency. Season the sauce with additional salt and pepper if needed.
To serve, spoon the rich sauce over the veal shanks and generously sprinkle with the fresh gremolata. Traditionally served with risotto alla Milanese or creamy polenta.

recipes.name: From-Scratch Chicken Pot Pie
recipes.description: Creamy chicken and vegetable filling in a flaky crust.
ingredients: For the Crust: 2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 cup cold unsalted butter (cubed), 1 tsp salt, 6-8 tbsp ice water

For the Filling: 500g boneless, skinless chicken breasts or thighs (halal), cubed, 4 tbsp butter, 1 onion, diced, 2 carrots, diced, 2 celery stalks, diced, 1/3 cup all-purpose flour, 2 cups chicken broth, 1 cup whole milk, 1 cup frozen peas, 1 tsp dried thyme, 1/2 tsp black pepper, 1 tsp salt, 1 egg (beaten, for egg wash)
instructions: First, make the pie crust. In a large bowl, whisk together the 2 1/2 cups of flour and 1 tsp salt. Add the cold, cubed butter.

Using a pastry cutter, two forks, or your fingertips, work the butter into the flour until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs with some pea-sized pieces of butter remaining. This will create a flaky texture.
Gradually add the ice water, one tablespoon at a time, mixing gently with a fork until the dough just begins to come together. You may not need all the water. Be careful not to overwork the dough.
Divide the dough into two discs, one slightly larger than the other. Wrap each disc tightly in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 1 hour.

Preheat your oven to 200°C (400°F). Season the cubed chicken with salt and pepper. In a large skillet or Dutch oven, heat 1 tablespoon of oil over medium-high heat. Cook the chicken until no longer pink, about 6-8 minutes. Remove chicken and set aside.
In the same pot, melt the 4 tablespoons of butter. Add the diced onion, carrots, and celery. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 8-10 minutes until the vegetables begin to soften.
Sprinkle the 1/3 cup of flour over the vegetables. Cook, stirring constantly, for 1 full minute to cook out the raw flour taste.

Slowly pour in the chicken broth and milk, whisking constantly to avoid lumps. Bring the mixture to a simmer, then reduce heat to low. Continue to whisk until the sauce thickens significantly, about 3-5 minutes.
Stir in the cooked chicken, frozen peas, dried thyme, 1 tsp salt, and 1/2 tsp pepper. Remove from heat and let the filling cool slightly.
On a floured surface, roll out the larger disc of dough to fit a 9-inch pie dish. Carefully transfer and press it into the dish. Add the cooled filling.

Roll out the second disc of dough to create the top crust. Place it over the filling. Trim any excess dough, then crimp the edges with a fork or your fingers to seal. Cut a few small slits in the top crust to allow steam to escape. Brush the entire top crust with the beaten egg wash.

Place the pie on a baking sheet (to catch any drips) and bake for 35-45 minutes, or until the crust is deep golden brown and the filling is bubbly. If the crust edges brown too quickly, cover them with strips of foil.
Remove from the oven and let the pot pie rest for at least 15 minutes before serving. This allows the filling to set, making it easier to slice and serve.

recipes.name: Detailed Thai Green Curry from Paste
recipes.description: Aromatic homemade green curry paste simmered with coconut milk.
ingredients: For the Green Curry Paste: 10 green Thai chilies (stemmed), 2 shallots (chopped), 4 cloves garlic, 1 stalk lemongrass (white part only, thinly sliced), 1 tbsp galangal (peeled and chopped), 1 tsp coriander roots (or stems), chopped, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/2 tsp white peppercorns, 2 tbsp cilantro stems, 1 tsp shrimp paste (optional, omit for vegan)

For the Curry: 2 tbsp vegetable oil, 1 can (400ml) full-fat coconut milk, 500g chicken breast (halal), sliced, or firm tofu, cubed, 1 tbsp palm sugar or brown sugar, 2 tbsp fish sauce (or soy sauce for vegetarian), 1 Asian eggplant (cut into chunks), 1 cup Thai basil leaves, 2 kaffir lime leaves (torn), 1 red chili (sliced, for garnish)
instructions: Begin by making the curry paste. If you have a traditional stone mortar and pestle, use it for the best texture. Otherwise, a small food processor works.

In the mortar or processor, combine the green chilies, shallots, garlic, lemongrass, galangal, coriander roots, cumin seeds, white peppercorns, and cilantro stems. Pound or process until a rough paste forms.
If using, add the shrimp paste and continue to pound/process until a relatively smooth, fragrant paste is achieved. This may take 10-15 minutes of pounding. Set aside.

In a large wok or pot, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. Scoop out the thick cream from the top of the coconut milk can (about 1/4 cup) and add it to the wok. Cook for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly, until it sizzles and the oil begins to separate.

Add 2-3 tablespoons of your homemade green curry paste (you can freeze the rest) to the wok. Fry the paste in the coconut cream for 3-4 minutes, constantly stirring and scraping the pan, until incredibly fragrant and the raw smell has cooked out.
Add the sliced chicken (or tofu) to the wok. Stir-fry for 2-3 minutes to coat it in the paste and sear the outside.
Pour in the remaining coconut milk and stir to combine. Bring the curry to a gentle simmer. Do not boil vigorously.
Add the palm sugar and fish sauce (or soy sauce). Stir until the sugar dissolves.
Add the eggplant chunks. Simmer for 10-15 minutes, until the chicken is cooked through and the eggplant is tender.
Taste and adjust seasoning, adding more fish sauce for saltiness or sugar for sweetness.
Just before serving, turn off the heat. Stir in the Thai basil leaves and torn kaffir lime leaves. The residual heat will wilt the basil and release its aroma.
Garnish with sliced red chili. Serve immediately with plenty of steamed jasmine rice.

recipes.name: French Onion Soup from Scratch
recipes.description: Deeply caramelized onion soup with cheesy bread topping.
ingredients: 1/2 cup dry white wine or dry vermouth
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
instructions: In a large heavy-bottomed pot or Dutch oven, melt the butter and olive oil over medium-low heat.
Add all the thinly sliced onions. Stir to coat them in the fat. Cover the pot and let the onions cook, steaming in their own moisture, for 15 minutes. This helps them soften without burning.

Uncover the pot, increase the heat to medium, and stir in the sugar. This will help with caramelization. Cook the onions, stirring every 5-10 minutes, for at least 45 minutes to 1 hour. It is crucial to be patient. The onions will slowly turn from white, to golden, to a deep, rich brown. Scrape the bottom of the pot as you stir to prevent sticking. This long, slow caramelization is what builds the foundational flavor of the soup.
Once the onions are a deep amber color, add the minced garlic and cook for one more minute.
Pour in the white wine to deglaze the pot, scraping up all the browned bits from the bottom. Allow the wine to simmer until it has almost completely evaporated.
Add the beef stock, bay leaves, and thyme sprigs. Bring the soup to a boil, then reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer gently for at least 30 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
While the soup simmers, preheat your oven's broiler. Arrange the baguette slices on a baking sheet and toast under the broiler for 1-2 minutes per side until dry and lightly golden. Set aside.
After simmering, season the soup generously with salt and black pepper. Remember, the cheese will add saltiness later. Remove the bay leaves and thyme sprigs.
Ladle the hot soup into oven-proof bowls placed on a sturdy baking sheet. Top each bowl with 1-2 slices of the toasted baguette.
Generously pile the grated Gruyère and Parmesan cheese over the bread and the edge of the bowl.
Carefully place the baking sheet under the broiler. Broil for 3-5 minutes, watching closely, until the cheese is completely melted, bubbly, and spotted with golden brown patches.
Remove from the oven with oven mitts—the bowls will be extremely hot. Let the soup cool for a few minutes before serving cautiously.

recipes.name: Chicken Biryani
recipes.description: A majestic layered rice dish where fragrant basmati rice and spiced chicken are cooked together (dum pukht), resulting in an aromatic and flavorful feast.
ingredients: 2 tbsp red chili powder (or to taste)
2 tbsp biryani masala (such as Shan or homemade)
3 cups basmati rice, soaked for 30 mins
1 tsp shahi zeera (caraway seeds) or cumin seeds
1 large onion, thinly sliced and fried until golden brown (birista)
A large pinch of saffron strands, soaked in 1/4 cup warm milk
instructions: Marinate the chicken: In a large bowl, combine yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, red chili powder, turmeric, biryani masala, salt, lemon juice, fried onions, mint, and cilantro. Add the chicken pieces, mix well, cover, and let it marinate for at least 2 hours, or preferably overnight in the refrigerator.

Cook the rice: In a very large pot, bring water to a rolling boil. Add all the whole spices and salt. Drain the soaked rice and add it to the boiling water. Cook until the rice is 70% cooked (it should still have a firm bite to it). Drain the rice completely and set aside.

Par-cook the chicken: In a heavy-bottomed pot (which will be used for layering), add the marinated chicken. Cook over medium heat for 15-20 minutes, until the chicken is partially cooked and the gravy has thickened slightly. There should be little to no water left. Remove from heat.
Layer the Biryani: Spread the cooked chicken and its gravy in an even layer at the bottom of the pot. Carefully layer the par-cooked rice over the chicken, spreading it evenly.
Add the garnish: Drizzle the saffron-infused milk over the rice. Sprinkle the fried onions, chopped mint, and cilantro on top. Dot with tablespoons of ghee.

Seal and cook on Dum: Cover the pot with a tight-fitting lid. If the lid is loose, seal the edges with dough or aluminum foil to trap the steam. Cook on very low heat (dum) for 25-30 minutes. Alternatively, you can place the pot in a preheated oven at 180°C (350°F) for 30 minutes.

Rest and serve: Turn off the heat and let the biryani rest, still covered, for another 15 minutes. To serve, gently fluff the rice from the side, ensuring you get both the rice and chicken layers in each serving.

recipes.name: Nihari
recipes.description: A luxurious, slow-cooked beef stew renowned for its rich, spicy, and gelatinous gravy. Traditionally cooked overnight and enjoyed as a hearty breakfast.
ingredients: 1 kg beef shank (nali), beef marrow bones, and/or beef brisket, cut into large pieces
2 tbsp Nihari masala (Shan or National brand), divided
1/2 cup atta (whole wheat flour) or fine besan (gram flour)
instructions: Sear the meat: In a large, heavy-bottomed pot (like a Dutch oven), heat ghee over medium-high heat. Add the beef pieces (not the bones yet) and sear on all sides until browned. Remove and set aside.
Fry the aromatics: In the same pot, add the sliced onions and fry until golden brown. Add ginger and garlic paste and sauté for 2 minutes until fragrant.
Add spices: Add 1 tbsp of the nihari masala, red chili powder, fennel powder, and turmeric. Stir for 30 seconds to toast the spices.
Cook the meat: Add back the seared beef, the marrow bones, and any remaining marinade. Add 8 cups of water and salt. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to the lowest possible setting.

Slow cook: Cover the pot and let it simmer very gently for 6-8 hours, or until the meat is extremely tender and falling off the bone. You can also use a slow cooker on low for 8 hours. Stir occasionally and add more water if necessary to maintain a gravy consistency.
Prepare the lagar (thickener): About 30 minutes before serving, take 1 cup of the hot broth from the pot and whisk it into the atta or besan in a separate bowl to make a smooth, lump-free paste.
Thicken the stew: Gradually whisk this paste back into the simmering nihari. Add the remaining 1 tbsp of nihari masala. Let it simmer for another 20-30 minutes until the gravy is thick and velvety.
Serve: The nihari should have a rich, glossy gravy. Serve piping hot in bowls, garnished generously with ginger, green chilies, cilantro, a squeeze of lemon, and fried onions, with naan on the side.

recipes.name: Haleem
recipes.description: A nourishing and hearty porridge made from wheat, barley, lentils, and meat, slow-cooked for hours until it reaches a thick, homogenous consistency. A Ramadan staple.
ingredients: 1/2 kg beef or chicken (boneless cubes or with bone for more flavor)
2 onions, sliced and fried until crisp (birista)
instructions: Soak grains and lentils: Soak the broken wheat and barley in water for at least 4-6 hours. Soak all the dals together in another bowl for the same amount of time.

Cook the meat: In a pressure cooker or large pot, cook the meat with ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, salt, and 4 cups of water until tender (about 20-25 minutes in a pressure cooker). Once cooked, shred the meat if using bones. Set aside with its stock.

Cook the grains and lentils: In a very large, heavy-bottomed pot, add the soaked and drained wheat, barley, and dals. Add 8 cups of water, salt, and turmeric. Bring to a boil, then simmer on low heat for 2-3 hours, stirring occasionally, until everything is completely mushy and blended.

Combine: Add the cooked meat and its stock to the pot of cooked grains and lentils. Use a large wooden whisk (mathani or muddler) to vigorously beat and mash the mixture for 15-20 minutes. This step is crucial to achieve the traditional sticky, stringy texture of haleem.

Slow cook: Add red chili powder and haleem masala. Continue to cook on very low heat for another 1-2 hours, stirring frequently with the whisk to prevent sticking at the bottom. The haleem is ready when it has a thick, porridge-like consistency and all components are fully integrated.
Prepare the tempering: In a small pan, heat 1/2 cup ghee. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Pour this hot tarka over the prepared haleem and give it a final stir.
Serve: Ladle the hot haleem into bowls. Garnish with fried onions, ginger juliennes, green chilies, cilantro, and a wedge of lemon.

recipes.name: Chicken Karahi
recipes.description: A bold and fiery dish where chicken is stir-fried and simmered in a wok (karahi) with tomatoes, green chilies, and ginger, creating a robust and minimally sauced curry.
ingredients: 1 kg chicken, cut into 12-14 pieces (skinless, bone-in for best flavor)
1/2 cup ghee, oil, or clarified butter
2 medium onions, finely chopped (optional, for a more Peshawari style)
4-5 medium tomatoes, finely chopped or pureed
2 tbsp red chili powder (or to taste)
1-inch piece of ginger, cut into juliennes
instructions: Heat the karahi: In a large wok (karahi) or heavy-based pan, heat the ghee or oil over high heat.
Sear the chicken: Add the chicken pieces and sear them until they turn white and are slightly browned on all sides. Remove and set aside.
Sauté base: If using, add the chopped onions to the same oil and fry until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 1 minute until fragrant.

Cook tomatoes: Add the chopped tomatoes and all the dry spices (coriander, cumin, red chili, turmeric, salt). Cook on medium-high heat, stirring frequently, until the tomatoes break down completely and the oil starts to separate from the masala (about 10-15 minutes).

Simmer chicken: Add the seared chicken back into the karahi. Stir well to coat every piece with the masala. Add 1 cup of water, bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low. Cover and simmer for 15-20 minutes, or until the chicken is fully cooked and tender.

Final frying: Uncover the karahi, increase the heat to high, and stir-fry the chicken for another 5-7 minutes. This step is key to achieving the classic dry-ish consistency of karahi. Cook until the oil separates again and the gravy clings to the chicken pieces.

Garnish: Turn off the heat. Immediately add the slit green chilies, ginger juliennes, and fresh cilantro. Sprinkle with crushed black pepper and drizzle with lemon juice. Give it one final gentle stir.
Serve: Serve immediately directly from the karahi, with fresh naan or roti.

recipes.name: Seekh Kebab
recipes.description: Skewers of finely minced meat, marinated with spices and herbs, molded around skewers, and grilled over hot charcoal for a smoky, juicy flavor.
ingredients: 500g beef or lamb mince (preferably with 15-20% fat)
1 medium onion, very finely chopped or grated
2 tbsp fresh mint leaves, finely chopped
1 tbsp raw papaya paste (or 1/2 tsp baking powder as a substitute tenderizer)
2 tbsp chickpea flour (besan), lightly roasted (optional, for binding)
instructions: Prepare the meat: In a large bowl, combine the minced meat with the grated onion, ginger-garlic paste, green chilies, cilantro, mint, and raw papaya paste. Mix thoroughly with your hands for 3-4 minutes. This helps tenderize the meat and develop the protein (myosin) for binding.
Add spices: Add all the dry spices and salt: coriander powder, roasted cumin powder, red chili powder, garam masala, and black pepper. Mix again until everything is well incorporated.

Check binding: Take a small portion of the mixture and press it into a ball. If it holds together, it's ready. If it feels too loose, add the lightly roasted chickpea flour and/or the egg. Mix well. Cover and refrigerate the mixture for at least 2-4 hours, or overnight for the best flavor.

Skewer the kebabs: Take a handful of the meat mixture and mold it firmly around a flat or thick metal skewer, forming a long, sausage-like shape about 1/2 inch thick. Press it firmly so it adheres to the skewer and is smooth on the outside.
Grill: Preheat a grill or barbecue to medium-high heat. Alternatively, you can use a grill pan or oven broiler. Brush the kebabs lightly with oil. Place the skewers on the grill.
Cook: Grill for 12-15 minutes, turning occasionally, until the kebabs are evenly cooked, charred on the outside, and firm to the touch.
Serve: Carefully slide the seekh kebabs off the skewers onto a plate. Serve immediately with mint chutney, onion rings, and lemon wedges.

recipes.name: Chapli Kebab
recipes.description: A signature Pashtun-style kebab from Peshawar. These spiced minced meat patties are characterized by their unique, coarse texture and are fried until delightfully crispy on the outside while remaining juicy inside.
ingredients: 500g beef or mutton mince (preferably coarse-ground with some fat)
2 medium tomatoes, deseeded and finely chopped
1 tbsp dried crushed pomegranate seeds (anardana powder)
1.5 tbsp corn flour or rice flour
1/4 cup fresh mint leaves, finely chopped
Oil or ghee for shallow frying
instructions: Prepare the base: In a large bowl, combine the minced meat, finely chopped onion, and tomatoes. Mix well with your hands. The moisture from the tomatoes and onions is crucial.
Add aromatics: Add the minced garlic, ginger, green chilies, crushed coriander seeds, crushed pomegranate seeds (anardana), and cumin seeds. Mix thoroughly.

Add herbs and binding agents: Add the chopped cilantro, mint, corn flour, and egg. Sprinkle in the red chili flakes and salt. Mix everything together vigorously for 5-7 minutes. This helps to bind the mixture and develop the texture.

Rest the mixture: Cover the bowl and let the mixture rest at room temperature for at least 30 minutes. This allows the flavors to meld and the flour to absorb excess moisture, which is key to preventing the kebabs from breaking during frying.

Shape the kebabs: Take a portion of the mixture (about a golf ball size) and flatten it firmly between your palms into a round, flat patty, about 1/2-inch thick. Traditionally, they are quite wide (like a chapli - sandal). Ensure the edges are smooth.
Fry the kebabs: Heat about 1/4 inch of oil or ghee in a wide, heavy-bottomed skillet over medium heat. Once the oil is hot, carefully place the patties in the skillet. Do not overcrowd the pan.
Cook until crispy: Fry for 4-5 minutes on the first side until deep golden brown and crispy. Gently flip and fry the other side for another 3-4 minutes until cooked through and equally crispy.
Drain and serve: Remove the kebabs from the skillet and drain on paper towels to remove excess oil. Serve immediately with naan, a side of yogurt sauce (raita), and a fresh salad.

recipes.name: Paya
recipes.description: A rich, hearty, and gelatinous soup made from slow-cooking goat or cow trotters (feet) with aromatics and spices. A beloved breakfast and special occasion dish.
ingredients: 8-10 goat or cow paya (trotters), cleaned and hair singed off
instructions: Clean the paya: Thoroughly wash the trotters. Scrape and clean the outside. They are often split lengthwise by the butcher for easier cooking.
Blanch: In a large stockpot, add the paya and enough water to cover them. Bring to a boil for 10 minutes. Drain and rinse the paya again. This removes impurities.
Sauté base: In a large, heavy-bottomed pot, heat ghee/oil. Add the sliced onions and fry until dark golden brown. Add ginger and garlic paste and sauté for 2 minutes.
Toast spices: Add all the whole spices (bay leaves, cinnamon, cardamoms, cloves, peppercorns) and sauté for 30 seconds. Then add red chili powder, coriander powder, and turmeric. Stir quickly.
Cook the paya: Add the blanched paya to the pot. Stir vigorously to coat them in the masala for 5 minutes.
Slow cook: Add enough hot water to fully submerge the paya by a few inches. Add salt. Bring to a boil, then cover and reduce the heat to the lowest possible setting.

Simmer: Let the paya simmer for 6-8 hours, or until the meat is incredibly tender and falling off the bone, and the broth has become thick and gelatinous. Stir occasionally and add more hot water if needed. Alternatively, use a pressure cooker for about 1.5 hours on high pressure after the first boil.
Adjust consistency: Once cooked, if the soup is too thin, increase the heat to medium and simmer uncovered to reduce it to your desired consistency. The traditional texture is thick and viscous.
Serve: Taste and adjust seasoning. Serve piping hot in bowls, garnished generously with ginger, green chilies, cilantro, and a squeeze of lemon. Enjoy with naan.

recipes.name: Sajji
recipes.description: A majestic Balochi dish featuring a whole lamb or chicken marinated only in salt and sometimes paprika, then slow-roasted over glowing embers for a stunningly smoky and succulent result.
ingredients: 1 whole lamb leg (approx 4-5 kg) or 2 whole chickens (approx 1.5 kg each)
3 tbsp paprika or Kashmiri red chili powder (for color, not heat)
instructions: Prepare the meat: Clean the lamb or chicken thoroughly. Pat it completely dry with paper towels. Using a sharp knife, make deep slits all over the meat, especially on the thicker parts. This allows the heat and salt to penetrate.

Apply the marinade: In a bowl, mix the salt, paprika, and black pepper. Rub this mixture vigorously all over the meat, pushing it into the slits. For authentic flavor, do not use any other marinade. Let it sit for at least 1 hour at room temperature.
Prepare the fire: The traditional method uses a special Sajji pit or a vertical skewer over a wood or charcoal fire. Let the flames die down to glowing embers and coal for consistent, radiant heat.
Skewer the meat: Impale the whole leg of lamb or chicken onto a large, sturdy metal skewer (seekh). Secure it well so it doesn't rotate loosely.

Roast: Position the skewered meat about 2-3 feet away from the heat source. Rotate the skewer slowly and continuously for 2-4 hours (depending on size). The goal is slow, even cooking until the skin is crispy and dark red, and the internal juices run clear.

Prepare stuffing (if using for chicken): While the meat roasts, prepare the rice. In a pot, heat oil and sauté onions until golden. Add cumin seeds, then drained rice. Add salt and water/stock. Cook until rice is done.

Rest and serve: Once cooked, remove the meat from the skewer and let it rest for 15 minutes. For chicken, you can stuff it with the prepared rice. Carve the lamb into large pieces. Serve on a large platter, traditionally with a side of 'Kaak' (hard, tandoor-baked bread) and a simple tomato-based dipping sauce or raita.

recipes.name: Aloo Gosht
recipes.description: A quintessential Pakistani comfort food and weekly staple. Tender pieces of meat and potatoes are simmered together in a spiced tomato-onion gravy, perfect with roti or rice.
ingredients: 500g beef or mutton, with bone (cut into pieces)
instructions: Sauté onions: In a pressure cooker or heavy-based pot, heat oil. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add sliced onions and fry until they are a deep, golden brown.
Create the masala base: Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 1 minute until fragrant. Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften and the oil begins to separate from the mixture.
Add spices: Add red chili powder, coriander powder, turmeric, and salt. Cook the masala for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly to prevent burning.
Brown the meat: Add the meat pieces to the pot. Increase the heat to medium-high and bhuno (fry) the meat, stirring constantly, for 5-7 minutes until it is no longer pink and is sealed on all sides.

Pressure cook: Add 4 cups of hot water. Close the lid of the pressure cooker and cook on high heat for 6-7 whistles, then lower the heat and cook for 25-30 minutes. If using a pot, cover and simmer for 1.5-2 hours until the meat is tender.

Add potatoes: Release the pressure naturally. Open the lid, add the quartered potatoes, and bring to a simmer. Cook uncovered for 15-20 minutes, or until the potatoes are tender and the gravy has thickened to your liking.
Final touch: Sprinkle garam masala over the curry and stir gently. If the gravy is too thick, add a little hot water.
Serve: Garnish with fresh cilantro and whole green chilies. Serve hot with naan or steamed rice.

recipes.name: Chicken Korma
recipes.description: A Mughlai-inspired delicacy featuring tender chicken simmered in a luxuriously creamy, mildly spiced, and nutty gravy. A celebration dish known for its rich aroma and subtle flavors.
ingredients: 1/2 cup fried onions (birista), ground into a paste
1/2 tsp red chili powder (or to taste)
A pinch of mace (javetri) and nutmeg (jaiphal)
1/4 cup raw cashews, soaked for 30 mins
2 tbsp melon seeds (magaz), soaked for 30 mins
1 tbsp poppy seeds (khus khus), soaked for 30 mins
instructions: Prepare nut paste: Grind the soaked cashews, melon seeds, almonds, and poppy seeds with a little water to form a smooth, thick paste. Set aside.
Sauté onions: In a heavy-bottomed pot, heat ghee/oil. Add the sliced onions and fry until translucent and soft, not brown.
Cook aromatics: Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute. Add the chicken pieces and bhuno (fry) on medium-high heat for 5-7 minutes until the chicken turns white.
Add spices: Lower the heat. Add coriander powder, cumin powder, turmeric, red chili powder, and salt. Stir well to coat the chicken.
Create the base: Add the whisked yogurt, one spoonful at a time, stirring continuously to prevent it from curdling. Cook for 5 minutes until the yogurt is well incorporated.

Simmer: Add the fried onion paste and the prepared nut paste. Stir well. Add enough water to come halfway up the chicken pieces. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 25-30 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and tender.
Finish: Uncover and cook for another 5 minutes if the gravy needs to thicken. The gravy should be smooth and creamy. Stir in the pinch of mace and nutmeg.
Garnish and serve: Just before serving, swirl in the fresh cream. Sprinkle with garam masala and garnish with sliced almonds and cilantro. Serve with naan or pulao.

recipes.name: Shami Kebab
recipes.description: An elegant and beloved kebab made from minced meat and chana dal, pan-fried to create a crisp golden exterior that gives way to a soft, flavorful, and finely textured interior.
ingredients: 1/2 cup chana dal (split Bengal gram), washed and soaked for 30 mins
instructions: Cook meat and dal: In a pressure cooker, combine the minced meat, drained chana dal, quartered onion, garlic, ginger, whole spices (peppercorns, cloves, cinnamon, cumin, red chilies), turmeric, and salt. Add enough water to just cover everything.
Pressure cook: Close the lid and cook for 5-6 whistles on medium heat, or until the meat and dal are completely tender and mushy. Let the pressure release naturally.

Dry the mixture: Open the cooker. If there is excess water, cook uncovered on medium heat, stirring constantly, until all the liquid evaporates and the mixture is thick and dry. Let this mixture cool completely.
Grind: Discard the whole cinnamon stick if possible. Transfer the cooled mixture to a food processor and grind until it forms a smooth, thick paste. Do not add water.
Season: Transfer the paste to a bowl. Add the finely chopped onion, green chilies, cilantro, mint, and garam masala. Mix everything well with your hands.

Shape the kebabs: Take a small portion of the mixture and shape it into a smooth ball. Flatten it between your palms to form a round, flat patty. Make sure there are no cracks. Repeat with the remaining mixture.
Shallow fry: Heat oil in a non-stick pan over medium heat. Gently place the kebabs in the pan and shallow fry for 3-4 minutes on each side, until golden brown and crisp on the outside.
Serve: Serve hot as an appetizer with mint chutney, ketchup, or a side of onion rings and lemon wedges. They can also be enjoyed as a sandwich filler in buns.

recipes.name: Daal Chawal
recipes.description: The quintessential Pakistani comfort food of creamy, tempered lentils served over steamed basmati rice. This version uses split yellow lentils (moong daal) for a quick and satisfying meal.
ingredients: 1 cup yellow split lentils (moong daal), washed and drained
1 tsp red chili powder (or to taste)
instructions: In a medium pot, combine the washed lentils, water, chopped onion, tomato, green chilies, turmeric, red chili powder, and salt.

Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 25-30 minutes, or until the lentils are completely soft and mushy. Stir occasionally and skim off any foam that forms on top. If the daal becomes too thick, add more hot water to reach your desired consistency.
While the daal is cooking, prepare the tarka. Heat oil or ghee in a small pan over medium heat.
Add the cumin seeds and mustard seeds. Once they begin to splutter, add the sliced garlic. Fry until the garlic turns light golden.
Add the thinly sliced onion and dried red chili. Fry until the onions are deeply golden brown and crispy.
Turn off the heat and add a pinch of asafoetida if using. Swirl the pan.
Once the daal is cooked, use a whisk to lightly mash the lentils for a creamier texture.
Pour the entire contents of the tarka pan over the cooked daal. It will sizzle dramatically.
Immediately cover the pot with a lid to trap the aromas for 2-3 minutes.
Garnish with fresh cilantro. Serve hot with steamed basmati rice and a wedge of lemon.

recipes.name: Aloo Baingan
recipes.description: A humble yet flavorful curry where soft potatoes and tender eggplant absorb a spiced tomato-onion gravy. A staple in everyday Pakistani cooking.
ingredients: 2 medium potatoes (aloo), peeled and cut into 1.5-inch cubes
1/2 cup neutral oil (mustard oil preferred for authenticity)
instructions: Soak the cubed eggplant in salted water for 15 minutes to prevent discoloration and reduce bitterness. Drain and pat dry before cooking.
Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed pot or wok (kadhai) over medium heat.
Add the cumin seeds and let them splutter for a few seconds.
Add the chopped onions and sauté until they turn soft and translucent.
Add the ginger, garlic, and green chilies. Sauté for another minute until the raw smell disappears.
Add the chopped tomatoes and all the dry spices (turmeric, coriander, red chili powder, salt). Cook until the tomatoes break down and the oil starts to separate from the masala, about 5-7 minutes.
Add the cubed potatoes. Stir to coat them in the masala. Cook for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add the dried eggplant cubes and gently mix everything together.
Add 1/2 cup of water, cover the pot, and simmer on low heat for 20-25 minutes, or until both the potatoes and eggplant are tender. Check occasionally and stir gently to avoid breaking the eggplant.
Once cooked, sprinkle garam masala over the top and garnish with fresh cilantro.
Serve hot with chapati or naan.

recipes.name: Bhindi Masala
recipes.description: Okra stir-fried with a blend of spices until perfectly crispy and non-slimy. A test of skill for any home cook, this dry curry is tangy, spicy, and utterly delicious.
ingredients: 1 tsp amchur (dry mango powder) or juice of 1/2 lemon
instructions: Wash the okra and pat them completely dry with a kitchen towel. This is the most crucial step to prevent sliminess.
Trim the ends and slice the okra into 1/2-inch pieces.
Heat oil in a wide, non-stick skillet or kadhai over medium heat.
Add the cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add the sliced onions and sauté until they become soft and lightly pink.
Add the ginger, garlic, and green chilies. Sauté for another minute.
Add the chopped tomatoes and all the dry spices (turmeric, coriander, red chili powder, salt). Cook until the tomatoes are mushy and the oil separates.
Add the sliced okra. Increase the heat to medium-high and stir-fry for 12-15 minutes. Do not cover the pan at any point, as the steam will make the okra slimy.
Keep stirring and frying until the okra is cooked through and develops a slightly crispy exterior.
Sprinkle amchur powder (or lemon juice) and garam masala. Mix well and cook for another 2 minutes.
Serve hot with chapati or paratha.

recipes.name: Palak Paneer
recipes.description: A classic North Indian-Pakistani curry featuring soft cubes of paneer cheese in a vibrant, creamy spinach gravy flavored with garlic and mild spices.
ingredients: 1/2 cup fresh cream (or 2 tbsp cashew paste for a lighter version)
instructions: Blanch the spinach: Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add the spinach and cook for 2 minutes. Immediately drain and transfer the spinach to a bowl of ice water to stop the cooking and retain its green color. Drain again and blend into a smooth puree. Set aside.
In the same blender, add tomatoes, onion, ginger, garlic, and green chilies. Blend into a smooth paste.
Heat ghee or butter in a pan over medium heat. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add the blended tomato-onion paste. Be careful, as it may splatter. Cook, stirring frequently, until the paste thickens and the raw smell disappears, and the ghee begins to separate from the masala.
Add all the dry spices (turmeric, coriander, red chili powder, salt) and cook for another minute.
Add the spinach puree and mix well. Bring to a gentle simmer. If the gravy is too thick, add a little water.
Add the paneer cubes and fresh cream (or cashew paste). Stir gently and simmer for 5-7 minutes on low heat, allowing the paneer to absorb the flavors.
Sprinkle garam masala on top. Serve hot with naan or jeera rice.

recipes.name: Matar Paneer
recipes.description: A beloved restaurant-style curry from North India and Pakistan, featuring soft paneer cubes and sweet green peas simmered in a rich, spiced tomato and onion gravy.
ingredients: 1 cup green peas (matar), fresh or frozen
8-10 cashew nuts, soaked in hot water for 15 mins
1 tsp Kashmiri red chili powder (for color)
instructions: Heat 1 tbsp of ghee in a pan over medium heat. Lightly fry the paneer cubes until golden brown on all sides. Remove and immediately soak them in warm water to keep them soft. Set aside.
In the same pan, add the chopped onions, cardamom, cinnamon, and bay leaf. Sauté until the onions are translucent.
Add the ginger, garlic, and green chilies. Sauté for another minute.

Add the chopped tomatoes and soaked cashew nuts. Cook until the tomatoes are soft and mushy. Let the mixture cool slightly, then remove the whole spices (cardamom, cinnamon, bay leaf) and blend into a smooth paste.
Heat the remaining 2 tbsp of ghee in the same pan. Add the cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Carefully add the blended paste (it will splatter) and cook over medium heat, stirring constantly, until the paste thickens and the ghee begins to separate from the sides.
Add all the dry spices (turmeric, coriander, red chili powder, salt) and sugar. Cook for 2 more minutes.
Add the green peas and 1 cup of water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 10 minutes until the peas are cooked.
Drain the water from the paneer cubes and add them to the gravy. Gently stir to combine. Simmer for another 5 minutes on low heat.
Sprinkle garam masala and drizzle fresh cream (if using). Garnish with fresh cilantro.
Serve hot with naan, paratha, or jeera rice.

recipes.name: Sarson Ka Saag
recipes.description: A hearty and iconic winter dish from the Punjab region, made from mustard greens slowly cooked with spices until deeply flavorful. Traditionally served with Makki ki Roti (cornbread) and a dollop of white butter.
ingredients: 1 large bunch mustard greens (sarson), roughly chopped
1/2 bunch bathua (lamb's quarters or goosefoot), optional but traditional
3 tbsp maize flour (makki ka atta) or cornmeal
instructions: Thoroughly wash all the greens (mustard, spinach, bathua) in several changes of water to remove any grit.
In a large pot, add the chopped greens, chopped onion, green chilies, ginger, and garlic. Add just 1/2 cup of water and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and let the greens steam and cook for 45-60 minutes, or until very tender. Stir occasionally and add a little more water if it sticks to the bottom.
Let the mixture cool completely. Using a hand blender or a traditional wooden masher (mathani), mash the greens to a coarse paste. For an authentic texture, avoid making it completely smooth.
Stir in the maize flour (makki ka atta) and salt. Simmer on low heat for another 20-30 minutes, stirring frequently to prevent burning. The saag will thicken and darken in color.
For the tempering (tadka), heat white butter or ghee in a small pan. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add the finely sliced onion and fry until deep golden brown and crispy.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry for 30 seconds. Add red chili powder and immediately pour this entire tempering over the cooked saag.
Mix well and simmer for a final 5 minutes. If the saag is too thin, mix 2 tbsp of cornmeal with a little water to make a slurry and stir it in to thicken.
Serve piping hot with a generous dollop of white butter, Makki ki Roti, and a small piece of jaggery on the side.

recipes.name: Chana Masala
recipes.description: A tangy, spicy, and incredibly flavorful chickpea curry that is a staple across Pakistan and India. Often enjoyed as a hearty breakfast with fried puris or as a main course with rice or naan.
ingredients: 1.5 cups dried chickpeas (chole), soaked overnight (or 2 cans, drained)
1 large black tea bag or 1 tbsp loose tea in a mesh ball (for color)
1 tsp baking soda (only if using dried chickpeas)
2 tbsp pomegranate powder (anardana) or 1 tbsp dry mango powder (amchur)
Thinly sliced onions, lemon wedges, and ginger juliennes for garnish
instructions: If using dried chickpeas: Drain the soaked chickpeas. Place them in a pressure cooker with 4 cups of water, the tea bag, black cardamom, bay leaf, and baking soda. Pressure cook for 15-20 minutes after the first whistle, or until very tender. Discard the tea bag and whole spices. Reserve the cooking water.
Blend the onion, tomatoes, ginger, garlic, and green chilies into a smooth paste.
Heat oil in a large pot. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add the blended paste and cook over medium heat, stirring frequently, until the mixture thickens and the oil starts to separate from the sides.
Add all the dry spices (coriander powder, cumin powder, red chili powder) and salt. Cook for another 2 minutes.
Add the cooked chickpeas (or canned chickpeas) along with 1-2 cups of the reserved cooking water (or plain water). Bring to a boil.
Mash a few spoonfuls of chickpeas against the side of the pot to thicken the gravy.
Reduce heat, cover, and simmer for at least 20 minutes to allow the flavors to meld.
Stir in the pomegranate or mango powder (anardana/amchur) for tanginess. Add garam masala and chaat masala.
Garnish with fresh cilantro. Serve hot garnished with sliced onions, ginger juliennes, and a squeeze of lemon, alongside puri, bhatura, or naan.

recipes.name: Halwa Puri (Classic Pakistani Breakfast)
recipes.description: A beloved weekend breakfast trio: sweet and fragrant semolina halwa, deep-fried fluffy puris, and a spicy, tangy chickpea curry (Cholay).
ingredients: 2 tbsp sliced almonds and pistachios for garnish
Approx. 3/4 cup water, or as needed
Oil for deep frying (ghee or vegetable oil)
2 cans (15 oz each) chickpeas, drained and rinsed (or 1.5 cups dried chickpeas, soaked overnight)
1.5 tsp red chili powder (or to taste)
1 tsp dried pomegranate seeds (anardana), crushed (or 1 tbsp lemon juice)
instructions: **Make the Cholay (Chickpea Curry):**
1. Heat oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add cumin seeds, black cardamom, cloves, and cinnamon stick. Sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant.
2. Add chopped onions and fry until golden brown. Add ginger-garlic paste and fry for another minute.
3. Add tomatoes and all dry spices (coriander, chili powder, turmeric). Cook until the tomatoes are completely soft and the oil starts to separate from the masala.
4. Add the drained chickpeas and salt. Stir to coat them in the masala.
5. Add 2 cups of water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat, cover, and simmer for at least 30-45 minutes. If using pre-soaked dried chickpeas, simmer until tender (may take 1-1.5 hours).
6. Once done, mash a few chickpeas against the side of the pot to thicken the gravy. Stir in crushed anardana or lemon juice. Garnish with cilantro and ginger. Keep warm.
**Make the Puri:**
1. In a large bowl, combine whole wheat flour, semolina, and salt. Mix in the 2 tbsp of oil.
2. Gradually add water and knead to form a firm, stiff dough (softer than roti dough but not sticky). Knead for 5-7 minutes until smooth. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest for 30 minutes.
3. Divide the dough into small lemon-sized balls. On a lightly oiled surface, roll each ball into a circle about 3-4 inches in diameter. Don't roll too thin.
4. Heat oil for deep frying in a kadai or wok over medium heat. To test, drop a small piece of dough; it should rise slowly.
5. Gently slide one puri into the hot oil. Press down lightly with a slotted spoon—it should puff up immediately. Flip and fry the other side for a few seconds until light golden brown.
6. Remove and drain on paper towels. Fry puris one by one. Keep them covered in a cloth napkin to stay soft and warm.
**Make the Sooji Halwa:**
1. Heat ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan on medium-low heat. Add semolina and fry, stirring constantly, for 12-15 minutes until it turns a deep golden color and smells nutty. Be careful not to burn it.
2. In a separate pot, bring 2.5 cups of water, sugar, and crushed cardamom to a boil.

3. **Crucial step:** Reduce the heat under the semolina to low. Carefully and slowly pour the hot sugar water into the roasted semolina, stirring vigorously with a long-handled spoon to prevent lumps from forming.
4. Continue to cook on low heat, stirring constantly, until the halwa thickens, leaves the sides of the pan, and becomes glossy (about 5-7 minutes).
5. Stir in saffron (if using). Garnish with nuts. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Paratha with Omelette
recipes.description: Flaky, pan-fried whole wheat paratha served with a spiced, fluffy omelette packed with onions, tomatoes, and green chilies.
ingredients: Approx. 1/3 cup water, or as needed
1 small tomato, deseeded and finely chopped
1/4 tsp red chili powder (or to taste)
2 tbsp oil or ghee for frying
instructions: **Make the Paratha Dough:**
1. In a bowl, mix flour and salt. Add oil and rub it into the flour.
2. Gradually add water and knead until a medium-soft, smooth dough forms (about 5-7 minutes). Cover and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
**Prepare the Omelette Mixture:**
1. Crack eggs into a bowl. Add all the chopped vegetables (onion, tomato, chilies, cilantro), spices, and salt.
2. Whisk vigorously until the eggs are frothy and everything is well combined. Set aside.
**Cook the Paratha:**
1. Divide the dough into two equal balls.
2. On a floured surface, roll one ball into a circle about 6 inches in diameter.
3. Smear a little ghee or oil over the surface. Dust lightly with dry flour. This is the key to flaky layers.
4. Make a cut from the center to the edge of the circle. Start rolling the dough from the cut edge into a cone shape. Press the pointed tip down to seal.
5. Flatten the cone with your palm and roll it out again into a circle about 7 inches in diameter.
6. Heat a tawa or griddle over medium heat. Place the paratha on it. Cook for about 30-40 seconds until bubbles appear. Flip.

7. Smear ghee/oil on the top side. Flip again and smear ghee/oil on the other side. Press down lightly and cook until both sides are golden brown with crispy spots. Repeat for the second paratha. Keep warm.
**Cook the Omelette:**
1. In a separate non-stick or cast-iron pan, heat 2 tbsp of oil/ghee over medium heat.
2. Pour the egg mixture into the pan. Let it set for a minute without disturbing.
3. Gently push the cooked edges towards the center, tilting the pan to let the uncooked egg flow to the edges.
4. Once the bottom is set and golden, carefully flip the omelette to cook the other side for another minute, or until fully cooked through.
5. Slide onto a plate and serve immediately with the hot, flaky parathas.

recipes.name: Hareesa
recipes.description: A rich, slow-cooked porridge of meat and wheat, originating from Punjab. It's labor-intensive, with a uniquely smooth yet textured consistency, and is often garnished with fried onions, ginger, and lemon.
ingredients: 1 kg mutton or beef with bone (shank is ideal)
1/2 cup short-grain rice (sela chawal), soaked for 2 hours
instructions: 1. **Initial Cook:** In an extremely large, heavy-bottomed pot, add the meat, soaked wheat (drained), soaked rice (drained), chopped onions, ginger-garlic paste, salt, chili powder, turmeric, and 1 cup of ghee/oil.
2. Add enough water to cover everything by about 2 inches (approx. 2-3 liters).

3. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to the lowest possible setting. Cover the pot and let it simmer gently for 5-6 hours. Check occasionally and add hot water if it looks dry; the consistency should be like a thick soup while cooking.
4. **The Key Step - Mashing:** After 5-6 hours, the meat should be falling off the bone and the wheat should be completely exploded and soft. Remove all bones from the pot.

5. Using a large wooden masher (ghotna), vigorously mash the mixture directly in the pot for 15-20 minutes. Alternatively, you can use a hand mixer on low speed for a few minutes. The goal is to break down the meat and wheat to create a thick, homogenous yet textured porridge. Do not blend it completely smooth.
6. Once mashed, continue to cook on low heat for another 30-45 minutes, stirring frequently to prevent sticking at the bottom. The hareesa should be very thick and pasty.
7. **Prepare the Tempering:** In a small pan, heat 1/2 cup ghee. Fry the thinly sliced onions until deep golden brown and crispy. Remove the onions and set aside.
8. In the same ghee, quickly fry the ginger juliennes for 30 seconds.
9. **Serve:** Ladle the hot hareesa into bowls. Drizzle the ginger-infused ghee over the top. Garnish generously with fried onions, green chilies, and cilantro. Serve with lemon wedges on the side.

recipes.name: Kheer (Pakistani Rice Pudding)
recipes.description: A classic, comforting rice pudding made by slow-cooking rice in milk until creamy, flavored with cardamom and saffron, and garnished with nuts.
ingredients: 1/2 cup basmati rice, soaked for 30 minutes
A pinch of saffron strands (soaked in 1 tbsp warm milk)
instructions: 1. Drain the soaked rice. Using a mortar and pestle or a food processor, lightly crush the rice so the grains are broken into 3-4 pieces each. This helps release starch and creates a creamier texture.
2. In a heavy-bottomed, wide pot, bring the milk to a boil. Keep a close eye to prevent it from boiling over.

3. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low. Add the crushed rice and crushed cardamom pods. Simmer gently, uncovered, for 45-60 minutes. Stir every 5-10 minutes, scraping the sides and bottom of the pot where the milk solids form.
4. As it cooks, the milk will reduce by almost half and become significantly thicker. The rice will become very soft and almost dissolve into the milk.
5. When the desired creamy consistency is reached, add the sugar and stir until completely dissolved. Cook for another 5 minutes.
6. Turn off the heat. Stir in the soaked saffron (with its milk), rose water (if using), and most of the nuts (save some for garnish).
7. Let the kheer cool to room temperature. It will thicken further as it cools.
8. Refrigerate for at least 2-3 hours to serve chilled. Garnish with the remaining nuts before serving.

recipes.name: Shakshuka (Pakistani-Style)
recipes.description: While North African in origin, this version has been adopted in Pakistani cafes with a local twist—spiced with cumin, coriander, and a hint of garam masala, making it a perfect brunch dish.
ingredients: 3 tbsp olive oil or neutral oil
1 small bell pepper (any color), finely chopped
2-3 green chilies, slit lengthwise (adjust to taste)
4 large ripe tomatoes, pureed (or 1 can crushed tomatoes)
Salt and black pepper to taste
instructions: 1. Heat oil in a large cast-iron or non-stick skillet with a lid over medium heat.
2. Add cumin seeds and let them sizzle for 30 seconds. Add chopped onion and bell pepper. Sauté until soft and translucent, about 5-7 minutes.
3. Add minced garlic, grated ginger, and green chilies. Sauté for another minute until fragrant.
4. Add all the dry spices (coriander powder, red chili powder, turmeric) and stir for 30 seconds to toast them.

5. Pour in the pureed tomatoes. Season with salt and black pepper. Bring to a simmer, then reduce heat to low. Cook uncovered, stirring occasionally, for 10-15 minutes until the sauce has thickened significantly.
6. Taste and adjust seasoning. Stir in garam masala if using.
7. Using the back of a spoon, create small wells or indentations in the sauce. Crack an egg directly into each well.

8. Season the eggs with a little salt and pepper. Cover the skillet with a lid and let it cook on low heat for 5-8 minutes, or until the egg whites are completely set but the yolks are still runny. For firmer yolks, cook for 1-2 minutes longer.
9. Remove from heat. Garnish generously with fresh cilantro, parsley, and crumbled feta or paneer if desired.
10. Serve immediately directly from the skillet with crusty bread, paratha, or naan for dipping.

recipes.name: Gajrela (Gajar ka Halwa)
recipes.description: Warm carrot pudding with milk and nuts.
ingredients: 1/4 cup silvered almonds and pistachios for garnish
instructions: In a large, heavy-bottomed pot or kadhai, heat 2 tablespoons of ghee over medium heat.
Add the grated carrots and sauté for 5-7 minutes until they begin to soften.
Pour in the milk and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to a simmer, stirring occasionally.
Cook for 45-60 minutes, until the milk has reduced and been mostly absorbed by the carrots. Scrape the bottom regularly to prevent sticking.
In a separate pan, heat the remaining ghee. Add the chopped nuts and raisins, frying until the nuts are golden and the raisins are plump. Set aside.
Once the milk is absorbed, add the sugar to the carrot mixture. Stir continuously for 10-15 minutes as the sugar melts and the mixture thickens.
Add the cardamom powder and the fried nuts and raisins (reserving some for garnish). If using, crumble in the khoya and mix well.
Cook for another 10 minutes until the halwa pulls away from the sides of the pan and has a rich, pudding-like consistency.
Garnish with reserved silvered nuts. Serve warm.

recipes.name: Zarda
recipes.description: Sweet saffron rice with nuts and raisins.
ingredients: 1 cup Basmati rice, soaked for 30 minutes
1/4 tsp saffron strands, soaked in 2 tbsp warm milk
1/4 tsp yellow or orange food coloring (optional)
Silvered pistachios and edible silver leaf (varq) for garnish
instructions: Drain the soaked rice. In a large pot, bring 4 cups of water to a boil. Add the rice and cook until it is 70% cooked (al dente). Drain and set aside.
In the same pot, heat ghee over medium heat. Add the cardamom, cinnamon, and cloves. Sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant.
Add the nuts and raisins, frying for a minute until the raisins plump up.
Add the drained parboiled rice and gently stir to coat it in the ghee and spices.
Sprinkle the sugar evenly over the rice. Do not stir immediately.
Drizzle the saffron-infused milk (and food coloring if using) over the rice.
Reduce the heat to the lowest setting. Cover the pot with a tight-fitting lid. You can also place a clean kitchen towel between the pot and the lid to trap steam.
Let the rice cook on 'dum' (steam) for 15-20 minutes. Do not uncover during this time.
After 20 minutes, turn off the heat and let it sit for 5 more minutes. Then, gently fluff the rice with a fork.
Garnish with silvered pistachios and silver leaf. Serve warm.

recipes.name: Falooda
recipes.description: Layered rose milk drink with vermicelli and ice cream.
ingredients: 2 scoops vanilla or pistachio kulfi / ice cream
1/4 cup falooda sev (thin vermicelli), cooked and chilled
2 tbsp sabja (basil seeds), soaked in water for 15 mins
instructions: Prepare the components: Cook the falooda sev according to package instructions, rinse in cold water, and drain. Soak the basil seeds in water until they form a gelatinous coating. Chill the milk.
In a tall glass, start assembling. Add 2 tablespoons of Rooh Afza syrup to the bottom of each glass.
Add a spoonful of soaked basil seeds over the syrup.
Next, add a layer of cooked and chilled falooda sev.
Slowly pour the chilled milk into the glass, leaving room for ice cream.
Stir gently with a long spoon to mix the syrup from the bottom.
Top with a large scoop of kulfi or ice cream.
Garnish with chopped nuts and a drizzle of more rose syrup.
Serve immediately with a straw and a long spoon.

recipes.name: Gulab Jamun
recipes.description: Deep-fried milk balls in sweet rose syrup.
ingredients: Ghee or oil for deep frying
instructions: First, make the sugar syrup. In a wide pan, combine sugar and water. Heat on medium until the sugar dissolves completely.
Add cardamom pods and saffron (if using). Let it simmer for 5-7 minutes until the syrup slightly thickens (1-string consistency). Add rose water, turn off the heat, and keep the syrup warm.
For the jamun dough, in a bowl, whisk together milk powder, flour, baking soda, and cardamom powder.
Add the ghee and mix. Gradually add milk, little by little, and gently combine to form a soft, slightly sticky dough. Do not over-knead. Cover and let it rest for 5 minutes.
Divide the dough into equal portions and roll them into smooth, crack-free balls. Ensure they are smooth to prevent cracking while frying.
Heat ghee/oil in a kadhai on low heat. The temperature is correct when a small piece of dough dropped in rises slowly to the surface.
Gently slide the balls into the medium-hot oil. Fry on low heat, stirring gently, until they turn golden brown. They will expand and double in size.
Remove the fried jamuns and drain excess oil. Then, immediately immerse them in the warm sugar syrup.
Let the jamuns soak in the syrup for at least 2-3 hours before serving, preferably overnight for best flavor. Serve warm or at room temperature.

recipes.name: Kulfi
recipes.description: Dense cardamom pistachio ice cream.
instructions: In a heavy-bottomed pan, bring the milk to a boil. Reduce heat to a simmer.
Stir frequently and simmer the milk for 45-50 minutes, scraping the sides and bottom, until it reduces to about half its original volume.
Add the milk powder and sugar, stirring continuously until the sugar dissolves and the mixture thickens further (another 10-15 minutes).
Add the cardamom powder, saffron, and chopped nuts. Mix well and cook for another 2-3 minutes. Remove from heat and let the mixture cool completely.
Once cooled, pour the kulfi mixture into kulfi molds or small airtight containers.
Cover the tops with aluminum foil or lids. Place in the freezer for at least 6-8 hours, or preferably overnight, until completely set.
To serve, remove the kulfi from the freezer. Run the mold under warm water for a few seconds to loosen it. Slide the kulfi onto a plate, garnish with more pistachios, and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Doodh Pati Chai
recipes.description: Strong, milky cardamom tea.
ingredients: 3 tsp loose-leaf black tea (or 3 tea bags)
instructions: In a small saucepan, add water and bring it to a rolling boil.
Add the crushed cardamom pods and let them boil for a minute to infuse the water.
Add the tea leaves, reduce the heat to medium, and let it simmer for 2-3 minutes.
Pour in the milk and add sugar according to your taste.
Increase the heat to bring the tea to a boil. Once it starts rising, lower the heat immediately.
Let it simmer for 2-3 minutes until the color changes to a rich caramel brown. For stronger tea, simmer longer.
Turn off the heat. Using a strainer, pour the tea into cups or a teapot.
Serve immediately with snacks or biscuits.

recipes.name: Lassi
recipes.description: Sweet yogurt-based mango drink.
ingredients: 1/2 cup mango pulp or 1 ripe mango, chopped
instructions: In a blender, combine the yogurt, chilled water (or milk), mango pulp, sugar, and cardamom powder.
Add a handful of ice cubes.
Blend on high speed until the mixture is smooth, frothy, and all the sugar has dissolved.
Taste and adjust sweetness by adding more sugar if desired. Blend again.
Pour into tall glasses. Garnish with a sprinkle of cardamom powder or chopped pistachios.
Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Rooh Afza Sharbat
recipes.description: Refreshing floral and fruit syrup drink.
ingredients: 3-4 tbsp Rooh Afza syrup (adjust to taste)
instructions: If using, soak basil seeds in water for 15 minutes until they form a gel-like coating. Drain.
In a glass, add the Rooh Afza syrup.
Add the soaked basil seeds (if using) and lemon juice.
Add a few ice cubes to the glass.
Slowly pour in the chilled water or milk.
Stir well with a spoon until combined.
Serve immediately as a refreshing drink.

recipes.name: Sugarcane Juice
recipes.description: Fresh pressed juice with lime and mint.
ingredients: 4-5 fresh sugarcane stalks (8-10 ft long total)
A pinch of black salt (kala namak)
instructions: Wash the sugarcane stalks thoroughly under running water. Peel off the hard outer layer with a knife.
Cut the stalks into smaller pieces that can fit into a juicer or extractor.
Pass the sugarcane pieces through a sugarcane juicer to extract the fresh juice.
Strain the juice through a fine mesh strainer or muslin cloth to remove any fibrous pulp.
Pour the juice into a jug. Add a pinch of black salt and squeeze in the juice of half a lime. Stir well.
Pour into glasses filled with ice cubes. Garnish with a mint leaf.
Serve immediately for the freshest taste.

recipes.name: Chapshurro
recipes.description: Meat-stuffed flatbread from Gilgit-Baltistan.
instructions: Prepare the dough by mixing flour, salt, and water. Knead until smooth and elastic. Cover with a damp cloth and rest for 30 minutes.
For the filling, heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and let them sizzle.
Add onions and sauté until translucent. Add garlic, ginger, and green chilies. Sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Add minced meat and cook until browned. Break it into small pieces as it cooks.
Add coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Cook until spices are incorporated. Let the filling cool.
Divide dough into golf ball-sized portions. Roll each into a thin round disk.
Place filling in the center. Fold edges to form a semi-circle or triangle. Seal edges firmly.
Heat oil in a deep pan. Fry Chapshurro until golden brown and crispy on both sides.
Drain excess oil on paper towels. Serve hot with chutney or yogurt sauce.

recipes.name: Namak Gosht
recipes.description: Simple salted meat dish from Pashtun cuisine.
instructions: In a kadai or frying pan, melt butter over medium heat.
Add ginger garlic paste and stir fry for two minutes until fragrant.
Add mutton pieces and sear over high heat to brown slightly.
Sprinkle salt. Add tomato quarters and green chilies. Do not stir.
Cover and cook for 5-10 minutes. Remove lid and take out tomatoes.
Remove tomato skins and return pulp to the pan. Mix well.
Cover and slow cook on low heat until meat is tender. Alternatively, add black pepper and water, then transfer to a pressure cooker. Cook until meat softens.
Once tender, evaporate excess liquid until fat floats on top.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve with parathas or rotis.

recipes.name: Khousay
recipes.description: Noodle and coconut curry with Burmese influences.
ingredients: Condiments: fried garlic, fried onions, boiled eggs, chopped coriander, chili oil, lemon wedges, fried crisps
instructions: For coconut curry: Heat oil, sauté garlic paste and turmeric for 1 minute.
Add coconut milk and whisk in toasted gram flour until no lumps remain.
Add salt and water. Simmer on medium heat for 30-45 minutes until thickened. Stir occasionally.
For chicken gravy: Heat 2 tbsp oil, sauté onions until light golden.
Add tomatoes and green chilies. Cook until tomatoes soften. Blend with water to a smooth paste.
Heat remaining oil, add cumin seeds, ginger, and garlic paste. Sauté until fragrant.
Add blended tomato paste. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add all spices: salt, black pepper, coriander, cumin, red chili powder, turmeric. Mix well.
Add chicken slices. Cook until color changes. Add 1 cup water and simmer until chicken is tender and oil surfaces.
Assemble: Place boiled noodles in bowls. Top with coconut curry and chicken gravy.
Garnish with condiments like fried garlic, boiled eggs, coriander, chili oil, and lemon wedges. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Siri Paye
recipes.description: Rich trotter and head meat stew.
ingredients: 1 set of lamb or goat trotters (paye)
1 lamb or goat head (siri), cleaned and cut
Fresh ginger juliennes, lemon slices, and green chilies for garnish
instructions: Thoroughly clean trotters and head pieces. Remove any hair and scrub well.
In a large pressure cooker or pot, heat ghee/oil. Fry onions until golden brown.
Add ginger and garlic paste. Sauté for 2-3 minutes.
Add all spices: red chili powder, turmeric, coriander powder, garam masala, and salt. Cook until oil separates.
Add tomato puree. Cook until the mixture thickens.
Add whisked yogurt. Cook for another 5-7 minutes, stirring constantly.
Add trotters and head pieces. Coat well with the masala.
Add water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 5-6 hours until meat is extremely tender and falling off the bone. Alternatively, pressure cook for 1.5-2 hours on low pressure.
Garnish with ginger juliennes, green chilies, and lemon slices. Serve hot with naan or rice.

recipes.name: Lahori Fried Fish
recipes.description: Crispy spiced fish fritters from Lahore.
ingredients: 500 g white fish fillets (tilapia, cod, basa), cut into strips
1 tsp cumin seeds, roasted and crushed
instructions: Pat dry fish fillets with paper towel.
Marinate fish with lemon juice, garlic paste, and salt. Set aside for 10 minutes.
In a bowl, mix gram flour, cornflour, rice flour, yogurt, ginger garlic paste, and all spices.
Add water gradually to make a smooth, thick batter.
Add marinated fish to the batter. Coat well. Let it sit for 15 minutes.
Heat oil in a deep pot over medium heat.
Fry fish in batches until half-cooked and coating is set. Remove and drain on paper towels.
Let fish cool for 15-20 minutes. Re-fry in hot oil until golden brown and crispy.
Drain excess oil. Sprinkle chaat masala immediately.
Serve hot with tamarind chutney or mint yogurt sauce.

recipes.name: Sindhi Biryani
recipes.description: Spicy biryani with potatoes from Sindh.
instructions: Fry sliced onions in oil until light brown. Remove 1/4 for garnish.
To remaining onions, add ginger, garlic, tomatoes, prunes, salt, red chili powder, and whole spices (cloves, cardamoms, peppercorns, cumin, cinnamon, black cardamom, bay leaves).
Fry until tomatoes are tender and water evaporates.
Add mutton, yogurt, and water if needed. Cook until meat is tender and water dries.
Boil potatoes until half-cooked. Add to meat with green chilies, mint, and coriander. Simmer 2-3 minutes.
Boil rice with salt, bay leaves, cinnamon, and black cardamom until half-done. Drain.
In a large pot, layer meat curry and rice. Start with rice, then meat, repeat.
Sprinkle food color, fried onions, and mint on top layer.
Cover tightly. Cook on low heat (dum) for 20-25 minutes until rice is fully cooked.
Let it rest for 10 minutes. Gently mix before serving with raita.

recipes.name: Daal Tadka
recipes.description: Tempered lentils, a daily staple.
ingredients: 1 cup yellow lentils (moong daal) or red lentils (masoor daal)
instructions: Rinse lentils thoroughly until water runs clear.
In a pressure cooker or pot, combine lentils, water, turmeric, and salt.
Cook until lentils are soft and mushy (about 15-20 minutes in pressure cooker or 30-40 minutes in pot).
Heat ghee/oil in a small pan for tempering. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add onions and sauté until golden brown. Add garlic, ginger, and green chilies. Sauté for 2 minutes.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft and pulpy.
Add red chili powder and cook for 30 seconds.
Pour this tempering over the cooked lentils and mix well.
Simmer for 5-10 minutes. Add garam masala and lemon juice.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with rice or roti.

recipes.name: Chicken Curry
recipes.description: Home-style tomato and onion curry.
instructions: Heat oil in a large pot. Add onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 2 minutes until fragrant.
Add chicken pieces and cook until they change color.
Add all dry spices (red chili, turmeric, coriander, cumin) and salt. Mix well.
Add tomato puree and cook until oil separates from the masala.
Whisk yogurt and add to the curry. Cook for 5-7 minutes.
Add 2 cups water, cover, and simmer until chicken is tender (20-25 minutes).
Add garam masala, green chilies, and lemon juice. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with naan or rice.

recipes.name: Beef Keema
recipes.description: Spiced minced beef with peas.
instructions: Heat oil in a pan. Add onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 2 minutes until fragrant.
Add minced beef and cook until browned, breaking up any lumps.
Add all dry spices (red chili, turmeric, coriander, cumin) and salt. Mix well.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft and oil separates.
Add green peas and 1/2 cup water. Cover and simmer for 15-20 minutes.
Add garam masala, green chilies, and lemon juice. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with naan or rice.

recipes.name: Bhuna Gosht
recipes.description: Slow-cooked spiced meat dish.
ingredients: 1 kg mutton or beef, cut into pieces
instructions: Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed pot. Add onions and sauté until dark brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 2 minutes until fragrant.
Add meat pieces and cook until browned on all sides.
Add all dry spices (coriander, cumin, red chili, turmeric) and salt. Mix well.
Whisk yogurt and add to the meat. Cook for 5-7 minutes.
Add 2 cups water, cover, and simmer until meat is tender (45-60 minutes).
Uncover and cook until most liquid evaporates and oil separates.
Add garam masala, green chilies, and lemon juice. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves. Serve hot with naan or rice.

recipes.name: Achar (Mango Pickle)
recipes.description: Spicy mango pickle condiment.
instructions: Wash and thoroughly dry mangoes. Cut into 1-inch pieces.
In a bowl, mix mango pieces with salt. Spread on a tray and sun-dry for 2 days.
Dry roast fenugreek, fennel, nigella, and mustard seeds separately. Cool and coarsely grind.
Heat mustard oil in a pan until it smokes. Cool completely.
In a large bowl, mix sun-dried mangoes with all spices and cooled oil.
Add vinegar and mix well. Adjust salt and spice to taste.
Transfer to a clean, dry glass jar. Seal tightly.
Keep in sunlight for 5-7 days, shaking the jar daily.
Store in a cool, dry place. Mature for at least a week before use.

recipes.name: Raita
recipes.description: Yogurt side with vegetables or herbs.
instructions: Whisk yogurt until smooth. Add water to achieve desired consistency.
Add salt, black pepper, and half of the cumin powder. Mix well.
Add your choice of vegetables (cucumber, onion, tomato) or herbs.
Garnish with mint, coriander, remaining cumin powder, and red chili powder.
Chill in refrigerator for at least 30 minutes before serving.
Serve as a cooling side dish with biryani or spicy curries.

recipes.name: Naan
recipes.description: Tandoor-baked leavened flatbread.
ingredients: Melted butter or ghee for brushing
Nigella seeds or garlic for topping (optional)
instructions: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water. Let stand for 10 minutes until frothy.
In a large bowl, sift flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.
Make a well in center. Add yogurt, oil, egg (if using), and yeast mixture.
Gradually add warm milk and knead for 8-10 minutes to form soft, elastic dough.
Place dough in oiled bowl, cover with damp cloth, and let rise in warm place for 2 hours.
Punch down dough and divide into 8 equal balls. Roll each into oval/teardrop shape.
If making garlic naan, press minced garlic into surface. For peshwari, stuff with nut and dried fruit mixture.
Preheat oven to highest temperature (500°F/260°C) with pizza stone or inverted baking sheet.
Dampen hands and slap naan onto hot surface. Bake for 2-3 minutes until puffed and golden.
Brush immediately with melted butter or ghee. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Roti/Chapati
recipes.description: Whole wheat unleavened daily bread.
instructions: Mix flour and salt in large bowl. Add oil and rub into flour.
Gradually add warm water, mixing until dough comes together.
Knead vigorously for 8-10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Cover with damp cloth and rest for 30 minutes.
Divide dough into 8 equal balls. Keep covered.
Heat tawa or griddle over medium-high heat.
Dust work surface and roll each ball into thin, round disc (6-7 inches).
Place roti on hot tawa. Cook for 30-40 seconds until bubbles appear.
Flip and cook other side for 30 seconds. For puffing, use direct flame or press with cloth.
Brush with ghee if desired. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Paratha
recipes.description: Flaky, layered pan-fried bread.
ingredients: 1 cup grated radish, squeezed (for mooli paratha)
Spices: salt, red chili, garam masala, chopped green chili, cilantro
instructions: Prepare dough as for roti (steps 1-4). Let rest 30 minutes.
For plain paratha: Roll ball into disc. Brush with ghee, fold into semicircle, then triangle.
Roll again into triangle or circle. This creates layers.
For stuffed paratha: Mix filling ingredients. Flatten dough ball, place filling in center.
Bring edges together, seal completely, and gently roll into circle.
Heat tawa over medium heat. Cook paratha on one side until bubbles appear.
Flip, brush top with ghee. Flip again, brush other side with ghee.
Cook until golden brown spots appear, pressing gently with spatula.
Serve hot with yogurt, pickle, or curry.

recipes.name: Roghni Naan
recipes.description: Soft, rich sesame-topped naan.
instructions: Activate yeast in warm water with sugar. Let stand 10 minutes until frothy.
In large bowl, mix flour, semolina, milk powder, and salt.
Make well. Add yogurt, oil, egg, yeast mixture, and warm milk.
Knead 10 minutes to form soft, slightly sticky dough.
Place in oiled bowl, cover, and let rise 2 hours until doubled.
Punch down. Divide into 8 balls. Rest covered 15 minutes.
Roll into ovals. Dimple surface with fingers.
Brush with water and sprinkle generously with sesame and nigella seeds.
Preheat oven to 500°F (260°C) with baking stone/sheet.
Bake for 2-3 minutes until puffed and golden. Brush with butter. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Kulcha
recipes.description: Leavened tandoor-baked bread.
instructions: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water. Let stand 10 minutes until frothy.
Sift flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt into large bowl.
Add yogurt, oil, milk, and yeast mixture. Knead to soft dough.
Cover and let rise 2 hours in warm place until doubled.
Punch down. Knead in cilantro, garlic, and kalonji.
Divide into 8 balls. Roll into thick circles (1/4 inch).
Prick surface all over with fork to prevent puffing.
Preheat oven to 500°F (260°C) with baking stone/sheet.
Bake for 2-3 minutes until lightly golden.
Brush with melted butter. Serve hot with chole or curry.

recipes.name: Sheermal
recipes.description: Saffron-infused slightly sweet bread.
ingredients: Slivered almonds and pistachios for garnish
instructions: Dissolve yeast in 1/4 cup warm milk with 1 tsp sugar. Let stand 10 minutes.
Soak saffron in 2 tbsp warm milk.
In bowl, mix flour, sugar, salt, and cardamom powder.
Add ghee/malai and rub into flour until crumbly.
Add yeast mixture, saffron milk, and remaining warm milk. Knead to soft dough.
Cover and let rise 1 hour until doubled.
Punch down. Divide into 8 balls. Roll into thick circles (1/2 inch).
Place on baking sheet. Score decoratively with knife. Press nuts into surface.
Brush with milk. Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 15-20 minutes until lightly golden.
Brush with ghee while warm. Serve with nihari or kebabs.

recipes.name: Purī
recipes.description: Deep-fried puffy bread.
instructions: Mix flour, semolina, and salt in bowl.
Add oil and rub into flour.
Gradually add water to form firm dough (firmer than roti dough).
Knead 5-7 minutes until smooth. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
Divide dough into 15 small balls. Keep covered.
Heat oil in deep kadai over medium heat.
Roll each ball into 3-4 inch circle. Keep thickness even.
Test oil: small dough piece should rise immediately.
Gently slide puri into hot oil. Press lightly with slotted spoon.
It will puff up. Flip and fry until golden brown (30 seconds per side).
Drain on paper towels. Serve immediately with halwa or chana.

recipes.name: Daal Masoor
recipes.description: The quickest lentil to cook, often prepared with a simple tempering of onions and garlic.
ingredients: 1 cup red lentils (masoor daal), washed and drained
2 tbsp fresh coriander leaves, chopped for garnish
instructions: In a pot, combine washed lentils, water, turmeric, and salt. Bring to a boil.
Reduce heat, simmer uncovered for 20-25 minutes until lentils are soft, skimming off any foam.
In a separate pan, heat oil. Add cumin and mustard seeds until they splutter.
Add onions and sauté until golden brown. Add garlic, ginger, green chili; cook for 1 minute.
Add tomatoes and spice powders (red chili, coriander). Cook until tomatoes soften.
Pour this tempering (tadka) into the cooked lentils. Stir well and simmer for 5 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and serve with rice or roti.

recipes.name: Chana Daal
recipes.description: A slightly thicker, heartier lentil dish, often cooked with spinach (palak) or squash.
ingredients: 1 cup split chickpeas (chana daal), washed and soaked 30 mins
instructions: Drain soaked lentils. In a pressure cooker or pot, combine lentils, water, turmeric, and salt.
Cook until tender (about 15-20 mins in pressure cooker or 40 mins in pot).
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds until they splutter.
Add onions and sauté until golden. Add garlic, ginger, green chili; cook 1 minute.
Add tomato puree and spice powders (red chili, cumin, coriander). Cook until oil separates.
Add spinach and cook until wilted. Pour this mixture into cooked lentils.
Simmer together for 10 minutes until flavors blend. Garnish with coriander leaves.
Serve hot with rice or naan.

recipes.name: Aloo Palak
recipes.description: Potatoes simmered in a spiced spinach puree. Nutritious and comforting.
ingredients: 1 large bunch spinach (palak), washed and chopped
instructions: Boil potatoes until tender but firm. Drain and set aside.
Blanch spinach in hot water for 2 minutes. Drain and blend to smooth puree.
Heat oil in pan. Add cumin seeds until they splutter.
Add onions and sauté until translucent. Add ginger-garlic-green chili paste; cook 1 minute.
Add tomatoes and spice powders (turmeric, red chili, cumin, coriander). Cook until soft.
Add boiled potatoes and mix well. Cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add spinach puree and salt. Simmer for 10 minutes on low heat.
Add garam masala and fresh cream (if using). Serve hot with roti or rice.

recipes.name: Gobi Aloo
recipes.description: A dry-ish stir-fry of cauliflower and potatoes with turmeric, cumin, and coriander.
instructions: Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds until they splutter.
Add onions and sauté until golden brown. Add garlic, ginger, green chili; cook 1 minute.
Add tomatoes and spice powders (turmeric, coriander, red chili). Cook until tomatoes soften.
Add potatoes and cook covered for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add cauliflower florets, salt, and mix well. Cook covered for 15-20 minutes on low heat.
Stir occasionally until vegetables are tender. Sprinkle garam masala and coriander leaves.
Serve hot as a side dish with roti or paratha.

recipes.name: Baingan Aloo
recipes.description: A simple curry where eggplant and potato are cooked together with basic spices.
instructions: Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds until they splutter.
Add onions and sauté until golden brown. Add garlic, ginger, green chili; cook 1 minute.
Add tomatoes and spice powders (turmeric, coriander, red chili). Cook until tomatoes soften.
Add potatoes and cook covered for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add eggplant cubes, salt, and mix well. Cook covered for 15-20 minutes on low heat.
Stir gently until vegetables are tender. Sprinkle garam masala and coriander leaves.
Serve hot with roti or rice.

recipes.name: Khatti Daal
recipes.description: A tangy lentil dish from Sindh, made tart with tamarind or dried mango powder (amchoor).
ingredients: 1 cup yellow lentils (moong daal or toor daal), washed
2 tbsp tamarind pulp or 1 tsp dried mango powder (amchoor)
instructions: Cook lentils with water, turmeric, and salt until soft (about 20-25 minutes).
Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin, mustard, and fenugreek seeds until they splutter.
Add onions and sauté until golden. Add garlic and green chili; cook 1 minute.
Add tomatoes and red chili powder. Cook until tomatoes soften.
Add this tempering to cooked lentils. Add tamarind pulp or amchoor.
Simmer for 10 minutes until flavors blend. Adjust salt and tanginess to taste.
Garnish with fresh coriander. Serve hot with rice.

recipes.name: Mooli Sabzi
recipes.description: A simple, dry dish of white radish cooked with spices, often eaten for breakfast with paratha.
instructions: Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds until they splutter.
Add onions and sauté until translucent. Add garlic, ginger, green chili; cook 1 minute.
